intro: Kohautia huillensis, commonly known as the Huillén mountain fern, is a rare and endemic species found in the high-altitude regions of southern Chile. It belongs to the family Blechnaceae and is characterized by its delicate, feather-like fronds that are typically less than 30 centimeters in length. The plant thrives in cool, moist environments, often growing on rocky substrates or in shaded forest understories. Its reproductive structures, including spore-producing sporangia, are located on the underside of the fronds, a common feature among ferns. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Kohautia huillensis is considered a vulnerable species, highlighting the importance of conservation efforts in its native range.
